title: Knee injury halts NSW State Cup final at Speers Point | The Maitland Mercury
body_text:
The Maitland Magpies have sent their best wishes to injured Charlestown Azzurri captain Jayna Fraser after a serious knee injury she suffered forced the Northern NSW Football Women's State Cup final to be abandoned at Speers Point on Sunday night.
Subscribe now for unlimited access.
or signup to continue reading
The NPL Women's top two teams were locked in a tight scoreless final, when Fraser went down in the 42nd minute of the Cup final at Lake Macquarie Regional Football Facility after twisting her right leg awkwardly in a challenge for the ball on Maitland's Paige Kingston-Hogg.
Play was halted with eight minutes remaining before the game was eventually abandoned due to a prolonged wait for an ambulance.
The Magpies and Azzurri were set to finalise this week on how to progress with the match.
Northern NSW Football general manager of football operations Liam Bentley said options included replaying the match, reconvening for a penalty shoot-out or declaring Maitland and Azzurri joint winners.
"We'll put a few of those options to the clubs, give them time to digest it and provide their input and then we'll come to a decision."
Azzurri coach Heath Whyte was hoping for the best but fearing the worst after a serious knee injury to Fraser.
It was quite distressing, actually, the pain that she was in.
- Azzurri coach Heath Whyte
"We couldn't move her," Whyte said yesterday. "It was quite distressing, actually, the pain that she was in. It was instant shock, and she was shivering and shaking.
"Fortunately, our goalkeeper [Danielle Bartels] is an ER [emergency room] nurse. Jayna was saying I can't feel my foot any more ... After two hours, we gave up [waiting for an ambulance] and we brought a car onto the field.
"She didn't like it, but we moved her. Danielle did a great job, and [Azzurri NPLW physiotherapist] Zoe [McLachlan] and [strength and conditioning coach] Col [Sanctuary]. They immobilised her leg, and it took quite some time, but we got her in the car and went straight to Lake Mac [private hospital] and they got some orderlies to help.
"It was getting to a point where she was just shivering uncontrollably ... and the pain was just excruciating.
"Everyone was great. Maitland were very supportive of the situation, Liam [Bentley], Peter [Haynes] from Northern were great. All concern was around the player."
The Cup final was 0-0 at the time of abandonment.
Azzurri, who were beaten by Olympic on penalties in last year's Cup decider, finished top of their group to advance to the finals.
They progressed to another final after beating Adamstown 1-1 (4-3) in a penalty shoot-out, while Maitland disposed of defending champions Olympic 4-0 in their semi-final.
Azzurri have already claimed the Charity Shield and League Cup this year.
They are second in NPLW on 33 points, five points behind leaders Maitland (38) with four rounds remaining.
Charlestown have a game in hand over the Magpies, and the premiership could be decided in a last-round showdown between the two sides.
Fraser's injury comes with Azzuri's leading scorer Madi Gallegos also sidelined due to a knee issue.
The State Cup was contested by 19 clubs from across northern NSW over three days at Speers Point.
Urunga beat Lake Cathie 1-0 in the Community Plate final on Sunday.
In NPL Men over the weekend, leaders Edgeworth (47 points) maintained a three-point buffer over second-placed Broadmeadow (44) with a 2-1 win against Cooks Hill (18).
Lambton improved to fifth place and 23 points by backing up their midweek win over third-placed Weston (31) with a 3-0 victory against Belmont Swansea (15). Weston succumbed 3-1 to Broadmeadow, Adamstown (14) drew 0-0 with Olympic (22) and Maitland (22) were 3-1 winners against Azzurri (24). Valentine (16) produced an important 2-1 victory over New Lambton (6).
